dismod_pde_csv
Headings-> Syntax Purpose CSV Files Infinity parameter.csv ---..age_grid ---..cohort_grid ---..debug_output measure_in.csv ---..ell ---..integrand ---..age_lower, age_upper ---..time_lower, time_upper ---..meas_like ---..meas_zeta ---..meas_sigma ---..meas_value ---..Covariates ---..Comments sfun_in.csv ---..Output Template ---..Input File ---..function ---..name ---..zeta ---..sigma ---..order effect_in.csv ---..integrand ---..covariate ---..lower ---..initial ---..upper sfun_out.csv ---..Scaled Residuals measure_out.csv effect_out.csv ---..integrand ---..covariate ---..effect Example
dismod_pde Command Line Program
Syntax
dismod_pde_csv
parameter.csv measure_in.csv sfun_in.csv
dismod_pde_csv parameter.csv \
measure_in.csv measure_out.csv \
sfun_in.csv sfun_out.csv \
effect_in.csv effect_out.csv
Purpose
Runs dismod_pde::optimize with inputs and outputs from and to csv files.
CSV Files
Each of the dismod_pde_csv command line arguments specify a dismod_pde csv file . This dismod_pde_csv uses the following csv files for its input and output:
parameter.csv
a small set of control parameters
effect_in.csv
measurement effects, limits, and initial values during fitting
measure_in.csv
defines the measurements
sfun_in.csv
stochastic function input values
sfun_out.csv
stochastic function output values
measure_out.csv
fitting residuals for each measurement
Infinity
These data files use the special values inf and -inf to denote plus and minus infinity.
parameter.csv
The command line argument parameter.csv specifies the parameter file. This file has only two columns, the first column name is name and the second column name is value. For each name, the following table contains a description of the corresponding value (that the modeler chooses). The order of the lines in parameter.csv is not important. All of the names must appear once and only once. Example value, used by get_started.sh , are listed below for each parameter.
name
Default
Description
age_grid
0 5 20
Age values in the computational grid.
cohort_grid
1940 1960 1980 200 2020 2040
Cohort values in the computational grid.
max_ode_step
1
Maximum step to use in age when solving for
S ( · )
and
C ( · )
.
print_level
5
Level of tracing printed by optimization (0 for no tracing).
max_iteration
80
Maximum number of iterations the optimizer should attempt before giving up.
converge_tolerance
1e-6
Optimizer convergence tolerance.
debug_output
0
More debugging output.
age_grid
The value corresponding to the name age_grid is a vector with elements separated by one or more spaces. It must be monotone increasing.
cohort_grid
The value corresponding to the name cohort_grid is a vector with elements separated by one or more spaces. It must be monotone increasing. The limits of the cohort grid must be large enough to surround the data in time.
debug_output
In parameter.csv file, this value must be either 0 (false) or 1 (true). If it is 1, more debugging output is displayed (possibly at the expense of slower execution).
measure_in.csv
The command line argument measure_in.csv specifies the measurement file which must contain the following columns:
Name Value
integrand
The integrand
used to model this measurement.
age_lower, age_upper
The age limits for this measurement.
time_lower, time_upper
The time limits for this measurement.
meas_like
name of the likelihood for this measurement.
meas_zeta
offset that is added before log scaling this measurement.
meas_sigma
standard deviation for this measurement.
meas_value
The value for this measurement.
Covariates
Zero or more covariate columns.
Comments
Zero or more comment columns.
Name Value
x_name
value of the specified covariate for this measurement
ell
We use
ℓ
to denote an index that starts at zero with the first value for each column. Since the first line contains the names for each column the first value for each column is in line number two; i.e.
ℓ = 0
corresponds to line number two.
integrand
The column with name integrand must have one of the following values: incidence, remission. m_excess, m_other, m_with, prevalence m_prevalence, m_specific, m_all, m_standard, relative_risk. We use
i ( ℓ )
to denote the value for the integrand; see optimizer integrand .
age_lower, age_upper
The column with name age_lower (age_upper) contains the lower (upper) limit for integration with respect to age for this measurement. The lower age limit must be greater than zero. We use
a l , ℓ
(
a u , ℓ
) to denote the corresponding limits; see optimizer age_lower, age_upper .
time_lower, time_upper
The column with name time_lower (time_upper) contains the lower (upper) limit for integration with respect to time for this measurement. We use
t l , ℓ
(
t u , ℓ
) to denote the corresponding limits; see optimizer time_lower, time_upper .
meas_like
The column with name meas_like must have one of the following values: gaussian (
h ℓ
= 2
), or laplace (
h ℓ
= 1
). We use
h ℓ
to denote which likelihood we are using; see optimizer meas_like .
meas_zeta
The column with name meas_zeta contains the offset
ζ ℓ
that is added to the measurement, and the model, before taking the log; see optimizer meas_zeta .
meas_sigma
The column with name meas_sigma contains the standard deviation
σ ℓ
for this measurement; see optimizer meas_sigma . If
σ ℓ
is infinity , the measurement is not included in the fit. If
σ ℓ
is zero, The measurement is treated like a constraint; i,e., the fit must agree with no residual.
meas_value
The column with name meas_value contains the values for this measurement
z ℓ
; see optimizer meas_value .
Covariates
Columns in the file measure_in.csv that have names beginning with the two characters x_ are covariate columns and corresponding measurement effects can be estimated; see effect_in.csv .
Comments
The file measure_in.csv may contain one or more comment columns. The corresponding column names begin with the characters c_:
sfun_in.csv
Output Template
If sfun_in.csv is the last command line argument, this is an output file and its contents only depend on the values in parameter.csv and measurement.csv . In this case, sfun_in.csv it is a template for the corresponding input file (when it is not the last command line argument). See the heading Input File directly below.
Input File
If sfun_in.csv is not the last command line argument, it is an input file with the column names listed below. You cannot change any of the column names; i.e., the names in the first row of the template version of
sfun_in.csv (see the heading Output Template directly above). The following values are fixed for each line and should not be changed:
Name
Value
age
age
a
corresponding to this line
cohort
cohort
c
corresponding to this line
time
time
t = a + c
corresponding to this line
function
stochastic function index
q
corresponding to this line
The following values are input for each line and should be chosen by the modeler:
Name
Value
optimize_zeta
offset added before log scaling of optimization problem
optimize_lower
lower bound for
s q
( a , c )
during the optimization procedure
optimize_initial
initial value for
s q
( a , c )
where the optimization procedure begins
optimize_upper
upper bound for
s q
( a , c )
during the optimization procedure
prior_like
direct prior likelihood name for
s q
( a , c )
prior_zeta
offset added before log in direct prior residual for
s q
( a , c )
prior_sigma
standard deviation for direct prior residual for
s q
( a , c )
prior_mean
direct prior value for
s q
( a , c )
age_like
age direction forward difference likelihood for
s q
( a , c )
age_zeta
added before log for age direction forward differences for
s q
( a , c )
age_sigma
standard deviation for age direction forward differences for
s q
( a , c )
age_order
order for age direction forward differences for
s q
( a , c )
cohort_like
cohort direction forward difference likelihood for
s q
( a , c )
cohort_zeta
added before log for cohort direction forward differences for
s q
( a , c )
cohort_sigma
standard deviation for cohort direction forward differences for
s q
( a , c )
cohort_order
order for cohort direction forward differences for
s q
( a , c )
cross_like
cross term forward difference likelihood for
s q
( a , c )
cross_zeta
added before log for cross term forward differences for
s q
( a , c )
cross_sigma
standard deviation for cross term forward differences for
s q
( a , c )
function
The value in the column with name function specifies the function for the corresponding line and has one of the following values : S, C, iota, rho, chi, or omega. For more details, see the stochastic functions
discussion in the optimizer documentation.
name
The columns with names prior_like, age_like, and cohort_like, must value gaussian or laplace. This specifies the corresponding likelihood for the residuals.
zeta
The columns with names prior_zeta, age_zeta, and cohort_zeta, contains the offset added before taking the log during the computation of the corresponding residuals.
sigma
The columns with names prior_sigma, age_sigma, and cohort_sigma, contains the standard deviation for the corresponding residuals.
order
The columns with name age_order and cohort_order must have value 1 or 2. These specify the order for the forward differences in the age and cohort directions. Note that the functions S and C can only use order 1 in the age direction.
effect_in.csv
The command line argument effect_in.csv specifies the measurement effect input information . This file has five columns with the following names: integrand, covariate, lower, initial, and upper.
integrand
The column with name integrand must have one of the following values: incidence, m_all, m_excess, m_other, m_prevalence, m_specific, relative_risk, or remission. We use
i ( m )
to denote the integrand for the m-th effect; see optimizer integrand .
covariate
Each value in the covariate column must be one of the covariate names in the measure_in.csv file (hence it must begin with the characters x_). Only covariate effects that appear in the effect_in.csv file are included in the fit. We use
n ( m )
to denote the covariate for the m-th effect; see optimizer covariate .
lower
The lower limit (constraint on fit) for this covariate effect. The value -inf can be used to denote minus infinity ; i.e., no lower limit.
initial
The initial value (where the optimization procedure begins) for this covariate effect. For each covariate effect, initial must satisfy
lower <= initial <= upper
upper
The upper limit (constraint on fit) for this covariate effect. The value inf can be used to denote plus infinity ; i.e., no lower limit. It is ok if
lower == initial == upper
in which case the corresponding value is used for this covariate effect, and it is not included in the optimization procedure.
sfun_out.csv
If this command line argument is present, this is an output file that contains information for each point on the computational grid.
Name
Value
age
age
a
for this line of the file
cohort
cohort
c
for this line of the file
time
time
t = a + c
for this line of the file
function
stochastic function index
q
for this line of the file,
estimate
final optimal estimate for
s q
( a , c )
prior_residual
direct prior residual for
s q
( a , c )
prior_scaled
scaled direct prior residual for
s q
( a , c )
age_residual
age direction residual for
s q
( a , c )
age_scaled
scaled age direction residual for
s q
( a , c )
cohort_residual
cohort direction residual for
s q
( a , c )
cohort_scaled
scaled cohort direction residual for
s q
( a , c )
cross_residual
cross term residual for
s q
( a , c )
cross_scaled
scaled cross term residual for
s q
( a , c )
Note that the output file has special structure in the following way:
Output lines are in groups of six with the same value for
( a , c )
; i.e., they corresponding to
s q
( a , c )
for
q = 0 , … , 5
.
The function index
q
on each line in a group of six is different corresponds to one of the following stochastic functions: S, C, iota, rho, chi, or omega.
Scaled Residuals
If a corresponding standard deviation
σ = 0
or
σ = ∞
, the scaled residual is zero.
Residuals that are not defined are set to zero. For example, the forward difference age residuals at the maximum age value.
If
0 < σ < ∞
, and it corresponds to a prior residual, the scaled residual is the residual divided
σ
.
If
0 < σ < ∞
, and it corresponds to a defined age (cohort) residual, the scaled residual is the residual divided
σ
times the square root of the corresponding age (cohort) values.
measure_out.csv
If this command line argument is present, all of the columns present in measure_in.csv
are copied to measure_out.csv . In addition, this output file that contains information for each measurement.
Name
Value
age
midpoint of the age interval for this measurement
cohort
midpoint of the cohort interval for this measurement
time
midpoint of the time interval for this measurement.
model
model value for this measurement, corresponding to estimate
adjusted
covariate adjusted value for this measurement
residual
residual value for this measurement, corresponding to estimate
scaled
scaled residual for this measurement, corresponding to the estimate
effect_out.csv
If this command line argument is present, each line of this file contains information for a measurement effect. This file has three columns named integrand, covariate and effect
integrand
The column named integrand specifies the integrand
column in the measure_in.csv file for this measurement effect.
covariate
The column named covariate specifies the covariate
column in the measure_in.csv file for this measurement effect.
effect
The value in the column named estimate is the MAP estimate for this measurement effect.
Example
The bash script get_started.sh is a simple example and test of dismod_pde_csv.
Input File: cpp/dismod_pde_csv.cpp
